Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SI2-SSI: Empowering the Scientific Community with Streaming Data Middleware: Software Integration into Complex Science Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will catalyze a new generation of sensor-based streaming data applications by building on the foundation of the Open Source DataTurbine (OSDT) middleware (www.dataturbine.org). This will involve strategic software development, systems integration and testing, science experiments, and education and outreach. The software developments will include (A) tools for configuring, testing, and controlling distributed sensor systems, (B) software interfaces that are compliant with the Open Geospatial Consortium Sensor Web Enablement standards, (C) a new OSDT-Matlab interface, and (D) OSDT cybersecurity enhancements. These software products will be integrated into the production research infrastructures at Purdue, the University of Connecticut, the North Temperate Lake LTER Network site, and the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute. The software will be professionally developed and managed as community resources. The intellectual merit of this project will be advances in software engineering, interoperability standards, and systems management for complex real-time sensor systems as well as advances on important open questions in civil engineering, marine science, and ecology. This project will yield broader impacts by enabling new science applications, enhancing productivity, and accelerating innovation across NSF directorates. To ensure that these broader impacts are realized, the team will provide student research opportunities, develop curriculum materials and training courses, and cultivate a community of software users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lakes are charismatic landscape elements widely used for recreation like sport fishing and water sports. Anthropogenic and climate change impacts have far reaching consequences when changing the quality of lake biotopes affecting everything from recreation to property values. The North Temperate Lakes (NTL) Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) Project is using lake buoys with sensors that measure certain water quality parameters in real time during the summer ice free season. The project we are reporting on here has developed the software infrastructure to automatically make these measurements available almost immediately for public consumption as well as for scientific research applications. Important steps for which software building blocks were implemented and developed include assuring that only high quality data are delivered. To achieve this, a system was developed that is capable of sending alert messages when certain conditions are met (e.g., no data, data outside of a pre-determined range) and eliminating or flagging such data as possibly erroneous. After assuring high quality the data need to be permanently and safely stored in a database from which they are made available online to other applications and the NTL website (https://lter.limnology.wisc.edu/). Several different pieces of software are needed to provide this chain of functionalities or workflow. This project identified appropriate tools and developed the glue between them that assures automatic processing of the data stream. Providing these data in real time allows organizations like the Clean Lakes Alliance to alert lake users to particularly poor conditions that may lead to health risks for swimmers. On a more positive side these data may also be used by sport fishers to determine optimal fishing depths and locations. Research applications are wide ranging and include detection of long term change as well as short term fluctuations in lake conditions.
